document.title: Test functions, distributions, and Sobolev’s lemma

para.p:
If
X
is a topological vector space, we denote by
X *
the set of continuous linear functionals on
X
. With the weak-* topology,
X *
is a locally convex space, whether or not
X
is a locally convex space. (But in this note, we only talk about locally convex spaces.)
The purpose of this note is to collect the material given in Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., chapters 6 and 7, involved in stating and proving Sobolev’s lemma.

Suppose that
Ω
is an open subset of
R n
. We denote by
⁢ D
( Ω )
the set of all
∈ ϕ
⁢
C ∞
( Ω )
such that
⁢ supp ϕ
is a compact subset of
Ω
. Elements of
⁢ D
( Ω )
are called test functions. For
= N
0 , 1 , …
and
∈ ϕ
⁢ D
( Ω )
, write
where

Math.text: formulae@(D ^ alpha = (D _ 1) ^ (alpha _ 1) * cdots * (D _ n) ^ (alpha _ n), absolute-value@(alpha) = alpha _ 1 + cdots + alpha _ n)

para.p:
For each compact subset
K
of
Ω
, we define

Math.text: D _ K = conditional-set@(phi element-of D * Omega, supp * phi subset-of-or-equals K)

para.p:
and define
τ K
to be the locally convex topology on
D K
determined by the family of seminorms
{ ∥ ⋅
∥ N
: N ≥ 0 }
. One proves that
D K
with the topology
τ K
is a Fréchet space. As sets,

Math.text: D * Omega = (union _ K)@(D _ K)

para.p:
Define
β
to be the collection of all convex balanced subsets
W
of
⁢ D
( Ω )
such that for every compact subset
K
of
Ω
we have
∈
∩ W
D K
τ K
; to say that
W
is balanced means that if
c
is a complex number with
≤
| c |
1
then
⊆
⁢ c W
W
. One proves that
{
+ ϕ W
:
∈ ϕ
⁢ D
( Ω )
,
∈ W β
}
is a basis for a topology
τ
on
⁢ D
( Ω )
, that
β
is a local basis at
0
for this topology, and that with the topology
τ
,
⁢ D
( Ω )
is a locally convex space. 1 footnote 1 1 footnote 1 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 152, Theorem 6.4; cf. Helmut H. Schaefer, Topological Vector Spaces, p. 57. For each compact subset
K
of
Ω
, one proves that the topology
τ K
is equal to the subspace topology on
D K
inherited from
⁢ D
( Ω )
. 2 footnote 2 2 footnote 2 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 153, Theorem 6.5.

We write
=

D ′
( Ω )

( Ω )

*

D ′
( Ω )
are called distributions. With the weak-* topology,
⁢
D ′
( Ω )
is a locally convex space.

It is a fact that a linear functional
Λ
on
⁢ D
( Ω )
is continuous if and only if for every compact subset
K
of
Ω
there is a nonnegative integer
N
and a constant
C
such that
≤
|
⁢ Λ ϕ
|
⁢ C
∥ ϕ ∥
N
for all
∈ ϕ
D K
. 3 footnote 3 3 footnote 3 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 156, Theorem 6.8.

For
∈ Λ

( Ω )

α

para.p:

para.p:
which shows that

The Leibniz formula is the statement that for all

Math.text: formulae@(absolute-value@(f * Lambda * phi) = absolute-value@(Lambda * f * phi) less= C * (norm@(f * phi)) _ N less= C * C ^ prime * (norm@(phi)) _ N, phi element-of D _ K)

para.p:
This bound shows that
⁢ f Λ
is continuous. ∎

The above lemma shows that
∈

para.p:
If
: f
→ Ω C

Math.text: formulae@(Lambda * phi = (integral _ Omega)@(phi * x * f * x * differential-d@(x)), phi element-of D * Omega)

para.p:
For
∈ ϕ
D K

Math.text: absolute-value@(Lambda * phi) less= (norm@(phi)) _ 0 * (integral _ K)@(absolute-value@(f) * differential-d@(x))

from which it follows that
Λ
is continuous. If
μ

R n

Math.text: formulae@(Lambda * phi = (integral _ Omega)@(phi * differential-d@(mu)), phi element-of D * Omega)

para.p:
For
∈ ϕ
D K

Math.text: absolute-value@(Lambda * phi) less= (norm@(phi)) _ 0 * absolute-value@(mu) * K

para.p:
from which it follows that
Λ
is continuous. Thus, we can encode certain functions and measures as distributions. I will dare to say that we can encode most functions and measures that we care about as distributions.

The following proof of Sobolev’s lemma follows Rudin. 12 footnote 12 12 footnote 12 Walter Rudin, Functional Analysis, second ed., p. 202, Theorem 7.25.

n , p , r

> n 0
